definitions.definition: a way or track that is built or is made by the action of people walking

examples.text: a dirt/gravel/concrete path
**Follow the path** through the woods.
They walked along the cliff path to the next town.
The **path led** up a steep hill.
a coastal path

definitions.definition: a plan of action or a way of achieving something

examples.text: Her sister followed a different **career path**.
There is no easy path to success.
Here are some pointers to set you on **the right path**.
The company cannot continue on its current path.
Our country is heading down the wrong path and needs to change.
The president urged the rebels to choose the path of peace.
So many people are seeking some kind of spiritual path.

definitions.definition: a line along which somebody/something moves; the space in front of somebody/something as they move
definitions.sensetop: into the path of somethingout of the path of somethingin something's/somebody's path

examples.text: Three men blocked her path.
He threw himself into the path of an oncoming vehicle.
We're trying to get people out of the path of the storm.
examples.contextForm: out of the path of something

examples.text: The avalanche forced its way down the mountain, crushing everything in its path.

definitions.definition: if a lot of people beat a path to somebody’s door, they are all interested in something that person has to sell, or can do or tell them

examples.text: Top theatrical agents are beating a path to the teenager's door.

definitions.definition: if somebody crosses somebody’s path or their paths cross, they meet by chance

examples.text: I hope I never cross her path again.
Our paths were to cross again many years later.

definitions.definition: to make somebody believe something that is not true
(to choose, etc.) the easiest way of doing something
an easy life that is full of pleasure but that causes you harm in the end
to make it easier for somebody/something to develop or make progress

examples.text: These negotiations are intended to smooth the path to a peace treaty.
We’re trying to smooth the way for women who want to resume their careers.

wordOrigin: Old English pæth, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch pad, German Pfad, of unknown ultimate origin.
